title: Studying and Presenting — Lecture 3 ((Re)Searching the Literature)

questions.prompt: Which description best fits grey literature in this lecture?

options.text: Scholar-authored, peer-reviewed primary studies
Reports, theses, and technical notes produced outside formal publishing
Magazines and news sites aimed at the general public
Unvetted social media posts

questions.explanation: Grey literature sits between scholarly and popular sources and includes reports, theses, datasets, and working papers.

questions.prompt: Select all criteria that belong to the CRAAP test discussed in the lecture.

options.text: Currency
Relevance
Authority
Accuracy
Purpose
Aesthetics

questions.explanation: CRAAP stands for Currency, Relevance, Authority, Accuracy, and Purpose.

questions.prompt: How should AI search assistants be used according to the lecture?

options.text: Treat AI summaries as substitutes for reading the papers
Use them to brainstorm queries but verify by reading the original sources
Rely on AI-generated references without checking
Avoid AI tools entirely

questions.explanation: AI can reformulate queries and surface concepts, but the lecture insists on opening and verifying the actual papers yourself.

questions.prompt: What is the recommended first step when starting a literature search?

options.text: Jump straight into a specialized database with no preparation
Begin with general exploration to harvest keywords and concepts
Limit yourself to one keyword you already know
Search only within the library catalogue

questions.explanation: The lecture starts the workflow with broad exploration (news, Google, Wikipedia) to build vocabulary before database searching.

questions.prompt: Which actions are part of snowball searching?

options.text: Following the references listed in a relevant paper
Checking newer papers that cite your starting article
Sorting results only by publication year
Reading only abstracts and ignoring citation links

questions.explanation: Snowballing works backward through reference lists and forward through citation tracking to expand coverage.

questions.prompt: What key information should every entry in your search log capture?

options.text: Database, query string, filters, and notes on results
Only the database name
Personal opinions about the lecturer
Screenshots of search pages without context

questions.explanation: The template tracks database, query, filters, outcome, and next steps to keep the process reproducible.

questions.prompt: If GetIt@Leiden does not provide full text, what is the recommended next step before requesting interlibrary loan?

options.text: Abandon the paper altogether
Check the catalogue, Google Scholar, or contact the author for a legal copy
Download from any random file-sharing site
Pay for the article out of pocket immediately

questions.explanation: The lecture recommends catalogue checks, Google Scholar OA links, or contacting the author before turning to interlibrary loan.

sources.heading: Slide 32 — How to get the article

questions.prompt: What is the rule for paraphrasing to avoid plagiarism according to the lecture?

options.text: Change a few words but keep the sentence structure and skip citation
Understand the idea fully, restate it in your own structure, and cite the source
Copy text verbatim if you cite it later
Avoid reading the original to stay unbiased

questions.explanation: The paraphrase protocol insists on grasping the idea, closing the text, rewriting in your own structure, and citing.

questions.prompt: Which reading flow does the lecture recommend for efficiently assessing a scientific article?

options.text: Read the paper linearly from start to finish without skimming
Skim title, abstract, figures, and conclusion before diving into intro and methods
Jump straight to the references
Only read methods and ignore conclusions

questions.explanation: The lecture outlines a staged approach: skim the big-picture sections first, then read introduction and methods before committing deeper.

questions.prompt: What is one recommended fix when your search returns too many results?

options.text: Swap AND for OR between different concepts
Add a more specific concept or apply filters like year or subject
Remove parentheses from complex queries
Disable all filters to see everything

questions.explanation: To tame large result sets, the lecture suggests adding precision with extra concepts and database filters and checking Boolean structure.
